PHYSICAL REVIEW B 106, 045115 (2022)
Differential entropy per particle as a probe of van Hove singularities and flat bands
Yelizaveta Kulynych 1 and D. O. Oriekhov 2 1Department of Physics, Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv, Kyiv 03680, Ukraine
2Instituut-Lorentz, Universiteit Leiden, P.O. Box 9506, 2300 RA Leiden, Netherlands
(Received 17 February 2022; accepted 29 June 2022; published 13 July 2022)
In the present paper we derive the general expressions for the differential entropy per particle near van Hove singularities (vHs) in the density of states. The dependence of entropy per particle on chemical potential and temperature demonstrates different behavior depending on the type of vHs, and distinguishes high-order vHs with different divergence exponents and flat bands. In addition, it allows one to test the “flatness” of the band in experiment. We compare the analytic predictions with the numerical calculation of the differential entropy for tight-binding models of graphene, the Lieb lattice, and the square-octagon lattice. Our results show that the obtained analytic expressions capture the main features of the differential entropy, thus serving as a good probe for details of the density of states structure.
DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevB.106.045115
I. INTRODUCTION
Entropy is a fundamental thermodynamic quantity that describes the state of a many-body system and governs its thermoelectric, thermomagnetic, and heat transport properties. However, the total entropy of the system is hard to measure directly, while the differential entropy per particle is accessible for modern experimental techniques [1]. The advantage of experiments performed in Ref. [1] is the design of the form of the flat capacitor with proper modulation of temperature, which is particularly suitable for studying properties of 2D materials. The differential entropy is calculated through the Maxwell relation s = (∂S/∂n)T = −(∂μ/∂T )n using the experimental data for evaluation of the second derivative. Recently, another set of experiments measuring differential entropy attracted great attention due to the observation of the isospin Pomeranchuk effect in twisted bilayer graphene [2,3]. In this set of experiments the differential entropy was extracted from the transport data.
The differential entropy per particle was proven to be a useful tool to probe the peculiar features of the band structure [4] and to show the presence of Lifshitz transitions with changing Fermi level [5]. In Ref. [6] it was shown that for two-dimensional electronic gas with parabolic dispersion the entropy per electron, s, exhibits quantized peaks which correspond to resonance positions of chemical potential at size quantization levels. The universal structure of these peaks was linked [6] to the topological Lifshitz transitions [7]. Later is was shown [4] that the entropy spikes in Dirac materials also correspond to the Lifshitz transitions, which occur at the boundaries of gapped bands.
The above-mentioned peaks and spikes of differential entropy [4–6] are the clear signatures of regions with vanishing density of states in the band structure. The goal of the present paper is to analyze the character of the differential entropy per particle in the opposite case, near the regions in band structure with diverging density of states (DoS). The classic examples
of such divergence of DoS are the van Hove singularities (vHs) [8] with logarithmic divergence and flat bands [9,10] with delta-function-like divergence [11]. Recently, a new class of DoS singularities was introduced, high-order van Hove singularities [12], which corresponds to power-law divergence of DoS. The corresponding band structure contains the so-called high-order saddle point at the energy level of this vHs [13,14]. While the usual saddle points occur in most two-dimensional materials due to periodicity of the Brillouin zone (BZ) [8], the high-order saddle points became a common feature of novel two-dimensional materials [12]. Several examples of such materials that host high-order vHs of different kinds are β-YbAlB4 [15], bilayer graphene with tuned dispersion via adding interlayer voltage bias [16], and Sr3Ru2O7 [17]. Recently it was also shown that the tight-binding model of monolayer graphene can host high-order vHs if the next- and next-next-nearest-neighbor parameters are included and tuned to special critical values [18]. Notably, the novel experiment has shown that the energy level of the usual van Hove singularity in monolayer graphene can be accessed using the special technique of very high doping [19].
The appearance of van Hove singularities near the Fermi level can lead to different prominent phenomena. One expected phenomenon is the chiral superconductivity in monolayer graphene, that is predicted to occur at the level of vHs [20]. When a high-order vHs is placed close to the Fermi level, one can expect the enhancement of density wave and Pomeranchuk orders together with the superconductivity [18]. The role of high-order vHs on different pairing types in twisted bilayer graphene was analyzed in Ref. [21]. For example, their presence in twisted bilayer graphene [22] can lead to valley magnetism [23], density waves, and unconventional superconductivity [24] such as topological superconductivity [25], the “high-Tc” phase diagram [26], and Kohn-Luttinger superconductivity [27].
In the recent papers [13] and [14] the classification of possible high-order van Hove singularities in 2D lattices with

different symmetry groups was performed. These results motivate us to analyze the differential entropy as an experimentally accessible quantity that can distinguish between different types of van Hove singularities. In the main text we derive the exact analytic expressions for the entropy per particle near the usual logarithmic and high-order van Hove singularities, and completely flat bands using the effective models for density of states [12–14]. Our expressions cover the whole range of known high-order van Hove singularities in 2D materials from Refs. [13,14] and have universal character as function of chemical potential divided by temperature. In addition, we compare the analytic expressions with numerical calculations for several tight-binding models (modified graphene [18] and Lieb lattice [10]) that host different types of high-order saddle points in dispersion. Then, we extend the analysis to the tight-binding model of the square-octagon lattice, where the dispersion has qualitative changes of type from saddle points to completely flat bands with changing model parameters [28–30]. The results for logarithmic van Hove singularities presented in the main text support the qualitative conclusions of Ref. [5] that the differential entropy has characteristic dip and peak structure, and passes through zero at the saddle point level. Notably, we find that the differential entropy near the high-order vHs level has even more pronounced features such as a dip or peak, and its behavior is fully defined by vHs type and temperature.
The paper is organized as follows: In Sec. II we present the main definitions and derive analytic expressions for differential entropy. Also we identify the distinguishing features of the entropy per particle that characterize vHs. Next in Sec. III we present the comparison of analytic expressions with numerical calculations of the differential entropy for DoS found from tight-binding models. Finally, in Sec. IV we discuss the obtained results and their qualitative consequences that can be observed in experiments. The technical details of the analytic derivations are discussed in Appendices A and B.

sections.heading: III. DIFFERENTIAL ENTROPY AS PROBE OF VHS TYPE
IN TIGHT-BINDING MODELS
sections.text:
In the present section we analyze differential entropy per particle for several lattice models hosting regular and high-order van Hove singularities, and flat bands. To analyze different van Hove singularities we first use the toy model from Ref. [18] of monolayer graphene with tunable next-nearest-neighbor and next-next-nearest-neighbor hopping parameters. In this model one can switch between the usual and high-order van Hove singularities by adjusting these parameters to specific values. Using this example, we study asymmetric high-order vHs with the divergence exponent of DoS α = 1/4. Next we take the pseudospin-1 tight-binding model which hosts ideal flat bands, the Lieb lattice. In this model one can analyze to which extent the flat band solely determines the differential entropy behavior as the strongly dominating feature in the density of states. Finally, we analyze the tight-binding model of the square-octagon lattice, in which
the most asymmetric type of high-order vHs is realized with one of D± coefficients equal to zero and α = 1/2. Also, by tuning the hopping parameters one can find two flat bands in this model, and we also briefly discuss such setting.

sections.heading: A. Graphene model with next- and next-next-nearest-neighbor hopping parameters

The lattice is schematically shown in Fig. 2(a). The tight-binding Hamiltonian on the basis of A, B sublattice components ψ = (ψA, ψB)T has the form

t3 → t3,c = (t1 − 2t2)/4 (22) one meets the high-order van Hove singularity instead of classical one [18]. The bands ε±(k) are plotted in Fig. 2 specifically for these relations of parameters (t2 = 0.2t1, t3 = 0.15t2). 2 and ρ is the proper dimensional parameter. The high-order vHs appears only in upper band, while in the lower band it is always the usual logarithmic vHs. We calculate its exact positions from ε±(k), taking the M1 point:
ε+(k = M1) = |t1 − 3t3| + 2t2, ε−(k = M1) = −|t1 − 3t3| + 2t2. (24)
In the upper plot in Fig. 2(c) we plot the density of states for the tight-binding model (14). The delta-functions in the density of states integrals (3) were regularized by introducing the finite energy level width in the form of Lorentzian shape with parameter :
δ(ε − Eλ) → 1 π 2 + (ε − Eλ)2 . (25)
The “width” is taken to be much smaller than the characteristic energy scale defined by the hopping parameter t and smaller than T to avoid important features from being hidden. Such level broadening can occur due to the presence of disorder, boundaries, defects, and electron-electron, electron-phonon interactions in real systems. The experiments suggest that can be of the order of 10 meV [33,34]. Recently the more detailed theoretical discussion of the role of disorder on DoS smearing was given in Ref. [35] using Born approximations. Here for the numerical calculations we took either = 0.005t1 or = 0.01t1 to check that results
do not strongly depend on choice as long as < T (room temperature is around T ∼ 20 meV in energy units). The integrals are evaluated numerically using an equally spaced grid with small enough discretization steps in kx, ky, and ε. To evaluate DoS, we calculate the spectrum in each point (kx, ky ) of discretization inside the first BZ and perform summation over bands using smeared delta functions (25). The energy integrals for the differential entropy [see Eq. (4)] are bounded on both sides with a cutoff parameter that is larger than the total bandwidth of the tight-binding model. This ensures that the contributions of all bands are included in the final result.
In the lower plot in Fig. 2(c) we plot the numerically calculated differential entropy as a function of chemical potential for T = 0.01t1. The interval of both upper and lower parts is selected such that it covers all characteristic features from the spectrum in panel (b). The analytic curve for sα (μ, T ) from Eq. (8) is plotted around the chemical potential level ε+(k = M1) with α = 1/4 and D+/D− = √ 2 as the red dashed line. It demonstrates good agreement with numerically calculated entropy per particle in the vicinity of the vHs level and predicts the slope of the curve that passes through zero. Away from that level it also describes the peak and reduction of differential entropy, but the precision is not so accurate. As was noted in Refs. [4,5], one should expect the manifestation of main features in entropy in the −T, T interval around the corresponding energy level. In our case the theoretical curve is plotted in the range −10T, 10T , and still remains mostly valid. On the smaller chemical potential the analytic formula predicts a less pronounced peak than the one that actually appears. The possible reason of such underestimation is the fact that the closely placed Dirac points [see panel (b)] induce the entropy spikes [4], and these spikes are partially merged with that coming from vHs. Notably, Eq. (9) that describes differential entropy per particle near the Dirac cone works well predicting the slope and its sign, but instead overestimates the height of the dip and peak structure. The latter may be caused by level broadening as DoS does not drop to zero at the Dirac cone if = 0 [4].
Finally, we analyze how the formula for differential entropy (10) works around the logarithmic vHs. Panel (b) in Fig. 1 suggests that the expected behavior is similar to the one observed in the vicinity of the usual vHs level in Fig. 2(c). There is some arbitrariness in choosing the ε0 parameter as it usually contains a momentum cutoff [12]. It is relatively hard to take it from tight-binding calculation of DoS, since there are other contributions and it is difficult to compare logarithms. However, this can be found by comparing the slope of the differential entropy curve with the theoretic prediction. In panel (c) we plot the analytic curve given by Eq. (10) with ε0 = 5t1 as the green dashed line. One should note that the parameter ε0 does not have strict physical limits as it comes as the normalization under the logarithm, and appears as a combination of constants in band decomposition and cutoff parameters over momenta in the effective model. We checked numerically that ε0 is of the order of 10t1 (thus, ε0 > 100T ). In Appendix B we perform estimation of ε0 using a more precise series expansion of dispersion around the M1 point, and find ε0 ≈ 13t1. This is in good agreement with numerical calculation. Also this result together with Fig. 1 shows that the slope of the slog function is always smaller that for sα at the

vHs chemical potential. However, we should again underline that the formula (10) has much less predictive power due to its nonuniversal character with the ε0 parameter inside. Below we analyze other systems to test the applicability of Eqs. (8) and (11) in different cases.

sections.heading: B. Flat-band system: Lieb lattice
sections.text:
The Lieb lattice is schematically shown in panel (a) of Fig. 3. It consists of three square sublattices, with atoms placed in the corners and in the middle of each side of the elementary cell. The corresponding tight-binding Hamiltonian was described in Ref. [10]:

It contains three bands, one of which is completely flat:
ε±(k) = ± √
2 + 4t2[cos2 (kxa/2) + cos2 (kya/2)], εflat = − . (27)
This model was experimentally realized in optical [36] and electronic lattices [37].
In the analysis of the Lieb lattice we concentrate on the differential entropy near the flat-band level. In the gapless case the two Dirac cones touch the flat band in the triply degenerate point k = (π/a, π/a). Thus, one would expect the appearance of spikes in differential entropy near level μ = 0. Also, the analytic expression (11) predicts that s(μ, T ) should pass through zero at μ = 0 and the slope is defined only by inverse temperature 1/T .
Panels (a) and (b) in Fig. 4 show the numerically calculated density of states in the upper plots [the level broadening
= 0.005t is taken to regularize delta functions; see Eq. (25)] and entropy per particle in the lower plots for the same range of chemical potentials. The difference between the two panels in the presence of the gap in panel (b) = 0.3t and in the temperatures (a) T = 0.01t , (b) T = 0.05t . We compare the analytic expression for the entropy near the flat band (red dashed curves) with the numerically calculated one. Both panels show good agreement between analytic predictions and numerical results. Note that despite the presence of Dirac cones that touch the flat band from both sides in the gapless case = 0 [10], the flat band solely determines the entropy behavior in the surrounding interval of chemical potentials due to the diverging density of states. Thus, the obtained results should also work for other flat-band systems such as the dice lattice, where the low-energy density of states has contributions from the flat band and Dirac cones [31,38], and the flat band is expected to be stable with respect to different perturbations [39–41].

sections.heading: C. Transition from high-order vHs to flat band: Square-octagon lattice model
sections.text:
Next we analyze the tight-binding model which is based on the square-octagon lattice [28,29]. This lattice attracted attention due to the possibility of existence of the stable graphene allotrope called T-graphene [42–44], stable MX2 (M = Mo, W; X = S, Se, Te) isomers [45], and Zn2O2, Zn4O4 monolayers [46]. It is schematically shown in panel (a) of Fig. 5. As was shown in the literature, besides the usual van Hove singularities the tight-binding model of the square-octagon lattice always hosts high-order van Hove singularities [30] and, in the special case of fine-tuned next-nearest-neighbor parameters, two exactly flat bands [47]. The Hamiltonian that describes the square-octagon lattice with nearest-neighbor (NN) t1,2 hopping parameters (between and inside small squares) and nextnearest-neighbor (NNN) hopping parameters τ (diagonals
045115-6
inside small squares) has the form
HT g(k) = − ⎛ ⎜⎜⎝
0 t2 t1eikxa + τ t2 t2 0 t2 t1eikya + τ
t1e−ikxa + τ t2 0 t2 t2 t1e−ikya + τ t2 0
⎞ ⎟⎟⎠. (28)
The spectrum defined by this Hamiltonian contains four bands. For arbitrary values of hopping parameters the exact expressions for energy bands are defined by fourth-order equations [28–30] and are very complicated. However, the expansions of the spectrum near saddle points are relatively easy to obtain. In Fig. 5 we plot several examples of the spectrum for τ = 0 with two different ratios of t2/t1: t2/t1 = 3/2 in panel (b) and t2/t1 = 1 in panel (c), and for τ = −t1 with t2/t1 = 1 in panel (d), where the two flat bands appear. As was noted in Ref. [30], the high-order van Hove singularities appear on the levels of flat lines ε = ±t1 for all values of t2/t1 if τ = 0. The position of flat lines can be shifted by nonzero τ hopping parameter, and for several critical values of τ the two bands become completely flat [47].
The characteristic singularity in DoS for high-order vHs, that comes from flat lines in the spectrum, is the same for all values of t2/t1 (we first analyze the case of τ = 0), and is given by
D(ε ≈ t1) = D0 {|ε − t1|−1/2, ε < t1,
0, ε > t1, D(ε ≈ −t1) = D0 {|ε + t1|−1/2, ε > −t1, 0, ε < −t1. (29)
This represent the limiting case of the vHs asymmetry, since one of the coefficients D+ and D− is zero. Also, this model has one of the strongest divergencies compared to lattices classified in Ref. [14]. In panels (a) and (b) of Fig. 6 we plot the numerically calculated density of states and the corresponding differential entropy, together with analytic expressions (8) (shown as red dashed lines). The temperature was chosen as T = 0.05t1 and the level broadening was set to be = 0.01t1. We especially selected a larger temperature than that in Sec. III A to check the applicability of analytic expressions when vHs are more pronounced. Notably, the results in Fig. 6 show very good agreement between Eq. (8) and numerical results. As was discussed in Refs. [29,30], in the t2/t1 = 3/2 case the flat lines are separated from upper (lower) bands by a large gap, and in the case of t2/t1 = 1 there are three-band-
touching points with two Dirac cones exactly at the vHs level. Still, the analytic expression works very well because the integrals in numerator and denominator in the differential entropy definition (4) are strongly dominated by vHs contributions. The plot range of analytic expression covers more than the [−4T,+4T ] interval around vHs. Also, one should note that zeros of the differential entropy appear near DoS extrema, as was qualitatively discussed in Ref. [5].
Also, the model contains logarithmic van Hove singularities that are related to the usual saddle points in the band spectrum. They are always placed near the M points (middle points on the sides of BZ), and for the τ = 0 case their energies are given by ∓t1 √ 1 + 4(t2/t1)2. In this case we plot the linearized expression of slog, which allows one to identify the characteristic parameter ε0. In panels (a) and (b) we shown
045115-7
the comparison of linear curves with the properly selected ε0 parameter versus numerical results for the differential entropy. We find a relatively large value of parameter ε0 = 9t1. However, here the slog(μ, T ) does not fully describe the differential entropy because the curve does not pass through zero exactly at the vHs point. One can relate this to the presence of an additional large constant density of states that surrounds vHs as is done at the end of Appendix A. In fact, taking into account the additional constant density of states, one finds the numerically observed shift of the differential entropy curve from zero for logarithmic vHs, but not for symmetric high-order vHs. In this sense the symmetric high-order vHs and flat bands as a limiting case demonstrate more stable qualitative features in s(μ, T ) than other types of DoS singularities.
Finally, we analyze the regime of the so-called “critical” value of the next-nearest-neighbor hopping parameter τ = −t1 (with t1 = t2), for which the two flat bands in the spectrum appear [47]. Such spectrum is shown in panel (d) of Fig. 5, and the corresponding DoS / differential entropy comparison is presented in Fig. 6(c). The exact energies of flat bands are εflat = 0, 2t1. We plot the analytic expressions from Eq. (11) for both cases and find very good agreement with numerical results. Also we should note that the peaks in s(μ, T ), that surround the flat-band zero, are the most pronounced features of the differential entropy in such regime. This is related to the fact that flat bands are placed near the spectral gap and band edge, respectively.

sections.heading: IV. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text:
In the present paper we derived the analytic expressions for the differential entropy per particle near the usual logarithmic and high-order (power law) van Hove singularities as well as flat bands. The important characteristic of the obtained results for high-order vHs and flat bands is the universality of the differential entropy expressions: they do not contain materialspecific constants apart from those characterizing the vHs type and the position of the flat band. The obtained expression for the differential entropy near the usual logarithmic vHs is not universal and contains a parameter that should be estimated from the effective theory which describes the saddle point in particular material or from numerical data.
For the case of high-order van Hove singularities the slope of the entropy curve and its shift from zero allow one to identify the type of vHs. In fact, one may expect that this approach of identifying vHs type can be more precise than measurement of DoS in the case of symmetric van Hove singularities. The reason is that the slope of the entropy curve as a function of μ/T immediately gives the divergence exponent. In addition, the obtained expressions show that the entropy near the flat band has the largest slope compared to all physically possible high-order van Hove singularities. The slope for logarithmic singularities is expected to be even smaller.
In Refs. [4,5] it was noted that zeros of the entropy per particle correspond to the extrema of the DoS curve as a function of μ. In addition, the logarithmic van Hove singularities manifest themselves as strong positive peaks and negative dip structures. Our results fully support these conclusions and generalize them to the case of high-order van Hove singularities. In fact, for the symmetric high-order vHs and flat band the structure of the differential entropy is qualitatively the same, but the peaks and dips have much larger amplitude than that around the logarithmic vHs level. For asymmetric
high-order vHs the pronounced peak or dip may be absent depending on asymmetry type.
We performed numerical calculations of DoS and the differential entropy for several tight-binding models: graphene with fine-tuned next- and next-next-nearest neighbor hopping parameters, the Lieb lattice, and the square-octagon lattice. Our analytic predictions show good agreement with numerical results. However, one important limitation of the obtained formulas is that the corresponding spectral feature in DoS should be well separated in energy from other possible features— other van Hove singularities, flat bands, or large constant DoS. The region where the analytic formulas are expected to work well is ±T from vHs or flat-band energy level. In the case when other spectral features are presented nearby, one should derive combined expressions, taking into account the corresponding DoS of all of them. However, such results quickly become very complicated and go beyond the scope of our paper. One of the interesting physical questions that have to be addressed elsewhere is how the merging of several van Hove singularities with changing model parameters is manifested in the differential entropy.
